sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/conductor/ma.message: update this value and the calculations based on this below.
update this value and the calcs based on it
Remove "non-AIO only" as it is no longer true.

Replace with:
            #      0.5 G - /boot
            #     20.0 G - /
            #    160.0 G - cgts-vg PV
            #   -------
            #    180.5 G min size disk
Delete these comments. If they belong anywhere it is in the kickstarts.

From what I can tell, these calculations are all horribly out of date. I can't even tell what they are supposed to mean anymore. I'm especially confused by this line:
167.0 G - PV for cgts-vg (specified in the kickstart)

I don't see 167 G specified anywhere in the kickstart. I see 193536 for <240G disks and 234496 for >240G disks. Is that what this is referring to?

OK - looking back through the kickstart history, I see that back on September 18, 2018, the pre_disk_aio.cfg was allocating 167G for the cgcs-vg PV. Since then, that number has been updated many times and the numbers here were never updated, even though the comments request that be done. We need a better way to manage this.

One propsal is converting these comments to python formulas computed automatically at runtime, that way any change will be instantly reflected here. We should do the same for the kickstarts.

Since this was not done in the beginning, problem with going from comments to formula is that it takes time to sort it out (var in contants.py don't really reflect what's here), I tried it once in the past but had to go back to updating these pesky comments due to lack of time.

Replace with:
            #     0.5 G - /boot
            #    20.0 G - /
            #   145.0 G - cgts-vg PV
            #   -------
            #   165.5 G min size disk

playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/resto.message: Why is there no backup? Keystone is now running in each subcloud and should be backed up.

In the current implementation the keystone database is dumped to the backup file only if `region_config=no`is in platform.conf.

During bootstrap the variable `region_config` is templated to platfrom.conf. Dcmanager overrides `region_config: yes` for bootstrap. Thus the subcloud won't have the keystone file in the backup.

For example we have 5 variables that try to handle dlrn hashes: delorean_hash_label, docker_image_tag, dlrn_hash_tag, dlrn_hash_tag_newest

So, when I want to know what a specific featureset has enabled I would need to grep the variables directory; and from there view each file to see what is enabled and what not. That seems to make that quite harder.

With this model, featureset will be deprecated. If you want to know what variables are passed to the job, you can launch the script passing the same prime variables as the job you want to analyze, and the output file of the script will anyway be logged. So for example if you want to know the value of freeipa_admin_password for the job ovb + ipa, you simple call the script specifying zuul.job: name_of_the_job, release: master, and you'll have in the output the full list of all variables passed. Also with the latest changes and introduction of standalon, featureset file doesn't always have the last word in terms of vvalues of the variables. That's the point now you have to lok at two different places to be sure what has been passed.
Here the analysis stops, and the proposal starts. Maybe mark it with a different Heading

I think we need to call everything that is here "constant", because you're not supposing to change any of these value anywhere except here. Also these are passed as --extra-vars, no possibility to change in the playbook, and these should really ahve the last word.

based on irc discussion with kashyap he has confimed that for kvm 'max' is always the same as 'host'

'host' exposes all the cpu flage form the host cpu that can be consumed by a vm.

my original concern was that max in KVM would result in cpu feature that qemu can emulated but are not present on the host beign exposed as well.

qemu has done this in the past on x86 allowing instruucton like avx to be emulated using sse4. this is not want we want.
such emulation causes both performacne gains where the applicaiton that need avx would not fall back to sse its self and performcne losses where the app world. 

the other concern with max is during a ruling upgrade or update it would prevent live mgiration form a new host to an old host as the new host will have more feature then the old and therefor the live migration should fail or the vm will crash if it every tried to use the instuction that is not supported on the old host.


this si basicaly unaviodable as in kvm mode we are froced to expose the host cpus in any case so this really only affects qemu with the tcg backend. givent that i think this makes sense as a default.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I think we should map hosts by its lowercase short name to avoid this kind of issues. Tobiko tobology name is always taken from the short hostname obtained from the name got trom hostname command so that we always have the same name for the same host everywhere. So when we get this info from other sources (IE OpenStack APIs) we should apply the same filtering before comparing names.

  short_hostname(my_name) == short_hostname(other_name)

where short_name could be defined as 

 def short_hostname(name):
      return name.lower().split('.', 1)[0]
Done

hooks/glance_utils.py.message: That's right, policy is effective immediately so no need to restart any services?

Correct, at least it should work like that!  oslo.config indicates that it re-reads policy files as soon as they change without needing to restart services.  Some services (such as keystone) DO need a restart.  I'm fairly certain that glance doesn't, but if it did, it would be the API.
Btw re: restart_handler, do services need to be restarted on policy changes? Or maybe restart is required when introducing a policy.yaml, but not when updating thereafter.
Good question.  It most likely gets introduced on the config-changed hook, and that almost always does a bunch of restarts.  So it should be good.
